overview: This subject will provide students with an overview of medications used in the treatment of psychiatric disorders, including their mechanisms of action and side effects. Students will gain an understanding of the role of psychologists in working alongside other health practitioners who prescribe and monitor these treatments. Students will also be introduced to a range of biological aspects of psychological functioning, including the role of endocrine factors in normal functioning and psychological disorders. Students will gain an understanding of the role of psychologists in developing interventions based on these biological perspectives.
ilo: Illustrate a comprehensive knowledge of the classes of psychotropic medications;
Recognise and appreciate the indications for the use of psychotropic medications;
Outline the pharmacological basis of the mechanism of action of psychotropic medications and their common side effects;
Recall topics in biological aspects of psychological functioning, such as sleep;
Recount the role of endocrine factors in psychological functioning;
Explain the biological mechanisms involved in high prevalence disorders, such as anxiety and depression;
Describe the biological mechanisms in psychological interventions for psychological disorders.

Prerequisites.content: Note: these subjects can also be taken concurrently (at the same time)

Inherent requirements (core participatio.content: Further details on how to seek academic adjustments can be found on the Student Equity and Disability Support website:http://services.unimelb.edu.au/student-equity/home

assessment.brief: 2 x MCQ quizzes based on material presented in Weeks 1-6
One written assignment based on material presented in Weeks 7-9
One written assignment based on material presented in Weeks 10-12

assessment.hurdle: Hurdle requirement of at least 80% attendance at all coursework and seminar activities associated with this subject.

date_times.contact_hours: 1.5 hours of lectures/seminars per week for 12 weeks
